entry.title: Objects
entry.content:
In this lesson

In this lesson, we learn about complex constructs through which rich functionality can be implemented: objects. We will see how objects allow us to create data structures tailored to our specific needs.

  1. Introduction to objects
  2. Looking back at strings
  3. Creating objects
    1. Classes
    2. Constructors
    3. Instance variables
    4. Methods

1. Introduction to objects

Much earlier in the course, when we introduced data types, we mentioned that there existed primitives, which could be expressed with a number, and objects, which were much more complex. We added that strings were our first type of object: being a sequence of character, no one number could adequately represent a string. Instead, we would store the address (a numerical value) of the location of the sequence of characters in memory.

Later, when we introduced collections, we mentioned that they were too complex to express as single numbers as well, and that just like strings, we would store the base address of our collections in memory and use indices to navigate from that base address to each value stored.

Now that we have a broader understanding of Python, we can complement our definition of objects:

Objects are complex structures that can contain variables and that can possess functions that define what it can do and how it can interact with internal and external data. The variables posessed by objects are called instance variables or attributes, and the functions are called methods.

2. Looking back at strings

For our purposes, we will not talk much of the instance variables belonging to strings. However, they do have a number of useful methods that can help you manipulate strings depending on your needs:

Method Effect
lower() Returns the string with all its characters converted to lowercase.
upper() Returns the string with all its characters converted to uppercase.
split() Splits a string into a list of characters and returns it.
strip() Removes space at the beginning and ending on the string and returns it.
replace(x,y) Replaces all the instances of x with y in the string and returns it.
find(s) Returns the index of the first occurrence of s in the string

To use any of these methods, you should always be mindful of applying it on a string: to call split() on a string variable S, for example, you would use S.split(). This differs from how we used functions in the past, which were used alone.

3. Creating objects

Now that we have a formal definition of what objects are, we need to look at how they are created. Objects are meant to be customizable structures through which you can implement new functionality adapted to the problems you are tackling. As such, we will combine what we have learned so far to produce them.

3.1 Classes

Classes are the containers that will hold our objects’ code. Much like other blocks, they possess scope and have a keyword associated with them: class:

class MyObject():
  #My object's code

We will not get into what classes can do for us beyond containing object definitions, but if you delve deeper into Python, you’ll see that they can do a lot more than that.

Note that just like other blocks, the code contained within a class is indented: failure to indent will result in errors. Similarly, scope applies to the class blocks, and anything declared inside of a class is only valid within that class.

The code we will store inside of classes is called a definition. By itself, an object’s definition simply outlines the blueprint of the object. We will see later that we can use that blueprint to produce our usable objects.

3.2 Constructors

The bare minimum required to build an object is a special method called a constructor. We have seen constructors before, when we talked about functions like str(), list() and dict(): their role is to initialize objects so that they are ready for use. Based on what we said about blueprints, we can now say that constructors will “follow the plan” outlined in the object definition and create an object instance.

Object instances are nothing more than “one copy of a structure that follows an object’s definition”. For example, "Hello" and "World" are both string instances: they are both strings as they follow the same blueprint, despite having different content.

To define our constructor, we will proceed the same way we did to create other functions: by using def:

class MyObject():
  def __init__(self):
    #My constructor's code

Our constructors always have the same name: __init__: this identifies them as a “special entity”. This name also makes it easier to remember what they do because they initialize an object – any code in the constructor is executed when the object is created and only then. This makes it a perfect place to create instance variables and prepare any structure that needs setting up.

In most cases, constructors will be used to create instance variables, which can be done through the self keyword included as the first parameter of our constructor. self refers to the “current object”, and can be used to execute other methods (as we’ll see in the next section) or to attach instance variables to our object.

For example, we can create two instance variables in our MyObject object by adding the following to our constructor:

class MyObject():
  def __init__(self):
    self.colour = "Blue"
    self.size = 2

By doing this, we are creating two instance variables within each object of type MyObject and we give them static values.

Once this is done, we can create an object of type MyObject at any time by typing:

my_obj = MyObject()

Note the similarity with the way we created lists through list().

Of course, constructors are methods, which themselves are functions: input parameters can be added to their signature:

class MyObject():
  def __init__(self, colour, size):
    self.colour = colour
    self.size = size

With this definition, we can now define the values of each instance’s colour and size instance variables. The new constructor can be called using MyObject("some colour", 5) or any variation thereof.

It’s very important to note that the self input parameter doesn’t need to be given to our constructor: it is implicitly defined by the object.

3.3 Instance variables

3.3 Methods

entry.title: Built-in modules
entry.content:
In this lesson

In this lesson, we will look at the interactive Python console. We will explore the notion of variables and methods, and review definitions that will follow us for the rest of our adventure.

  1. Using the interactive console
  2. Variables
    1. Primitives and Objects
    2. Creating and modifying variables

1. Using the interactive console

For the first part of this lesson, you can use the interactive console through a Command Prompt/Terminal (by opening a Command Prompt/Terminal and typing python) or through IDLE. Since IDLE’s interactive console is just a graphical interface wrapped around the regular Python console, you shouldn’t see any difference in function.

Before we get started, consider a few things about the interactive console:

  1. It has memory. Any variable or method defined in the console will exist and be accessible until the console is terminated. This allows us to type long scripts one statement at a time and keep the results of each statement at hand for the next;
  2. It can be terminated at any time by using the exit statement exit();
  3. If the console is busy with a task, you can force termination using the Control/Command key and C, this is called a keyboard interrupt;
  4. Any statement that produces output will print out its output on the line following a statement;
  5. You can view the contents of a variable at any time by using its name as a statement.

1.1 Mathematical operations

The most basic thing the interactive console can do it basic arithmetic. If you use any mathematical operation as a statement, you should see the results printed below. All the basic operators taught in algebra are valid. As such, we can experiment and produce the following:

Various arithmetic operations in the console

Note that just like in classical algebra, you can use parentheses to group operations together, and chained operations such as (1 + 1) * (12 * 50) can be composed from simpler ones.

2. Variables

What differentiates the interactive console from a simple pocket calculator is its ability to store and manipulate different kinds of data. To achieve this, we will use variables. Variables in Python are no different from their algebraic counterparts: they act as a symbolic replacement for data. This means that once defined, a variable can be inserted in other operations and behave as if you had inserted the data is contains.

Before we create our own, however, we should define a few basic data types available in Python: these data types will determine what kind of data is stored in a variable and what sort of operations we can apply on said variable.

2.1 Primitives and Objects

Python data types can be separated into two classes: primitives and objects. The separating criterion is fairly simple: primitives can be represented by a single numerical value while objects require a bigger structure stored in memory, to which the variable points. Below are the three main primitive types we will be using most of the time:

Data type Definition Example values
int Integer values 1, -1, 2000000
float Floating-point values 1.1, -1.5
boolean True or false binary values True, False

In addition to these types, we need to define at least one object type: the string. Strings are collections of characters and can contain single characters, words, sentences and even entire books.

Data type Definition Example values
str Strings, any set of character surrounded by single or double quotation marks "Hello, world!", "A"

2.2 Operations on primitives

All of the arithmetic operations we have experimented with in the [first section] of this lesson are applicable to any primitive. In the case of True and False (boolean values), those will be interpreted as 1 and 0 respectively. As such, the following is possible:

Arithmetic using boolean values

This outlines what we said earlier: any primitive value can be represented as a number.

2.3 Operations on objects

Operations on objects are a bit trickier. Because objects are complex structures, no two object types have the same operations! Because object operations are defined on a case by case basis, we’ll look at the one object we considered so far: the string.

While strings cannot be divided or subtracted from one another, two operations exist:

Operation Definition
+ Concatenation, or the union of two or more strings
* Multiplication, or the act of repeating strings

The first operation, concatenation, allows you to make longer strings out of shorter ones. This means that given three strings, we can use the + operator to form a new longer one that represents the sum of the three:

Concatenating strings

The same way, using the * operator will duplicate and concatenate strings. For example, typing "hello" * 2 would result in the string "hellohello"; the initial string would be repeated twice, and the repetitions concatenated.

2.4 Operations and data types

The operations defined earlier only apply between items of the same type (either primitive or object). As such, while you can add a float to an int, you cannot concatenate a string to a number directly as either element has a different definition of what the operation + should do. To solve this issue, you can convert one data type to the other, when possible. To do so, we will introduce three functions (also called methods):

Method Definition
str(x) If possible, converts the value x to a string. This would, for example, convert the integer 1 to the string "1".
int(x) If possible, converts the value x to an integer.
float(x) If possible, convers the value x to a float.

These conversions are limited: only strings representing numbers can be converted to proper numbers using float(x) and int(x), but any float, integer or boolean can be converted to a string using str(x).

We can use these functions to combine data of different types. Using this, we could write the following statement:

"Hello! I am " + str(27) + " and I like Python."

Without the type conversion, an error would occur:

TypeError during concatenation

2.2 Creating and modifying variables

As we’ve seen in the previous sections, we can easily manipulate raw data in the interactive console. However, one large issue that stops us from going forward is data persistence. While we can apply operations on numbers and strings, we have yet to save anything to memory! This is where variables come in. As we said earlier, variables are symbolic replacements for data. Once defined, a variable and the data is contains can be substituted in any other statement.

Python being a soft-typed language, we do not need to handle which data type each variable stores; the interpreter will handle that seamlessly as we use our variables. This results in a very simple model for the definition of variables:

my_variable = some_value

entry.title: Control flow
entry.content:
In this lesson

In this lesson, we discuss iteration and iterative structures. These structures will allow us to repeat operations without having to duplicate code. Ultimately, this will also facilitate data processing by allowing us to “walk” through certain bundles of data.

  1. The value of iteration
  2. Loop structures
    1. while loops
    2. for loops
    3. Converting while to for and back
  3. Concrete examples

1. The value of iteration

Iterative structures are all about repetition. One of the main perks of harnessing Python’s power to do various tasks is its ability to repeat operations very fast, effectively taking care of well-defined processing jobs as fast as possible. Whether the goal is to sort a collection of items, to find the solution to a Sudoku puzzle or to calculate the interest you might gain from future savings, the idea of repeating a set of statements a certain number of times or until a certain state is reached is usually part of the solution.

In Python, loops will allow us to repeat blocks of code at will. This will, amongst other things, allow us to avoid repeating similar sets of statements, kind of like how we captured simple sequences in functions. They will also allow us to repeat parts of our scripts until certain conditions are met; in the case of user input, for example, we could choose to ask the question again and again, until the answer is satisfactory.

2. Loop structures

Python gives us two categories of loops: while and for loops. The difference between the two is purely semantic and everything that can be done with one can be done with the other, albeit with different syntax.

2.1 while loops

while loops implement the function “repeat x as long as condition holds”, which makes them very similar with conditional statements. In fact, they will share a structure almost identical to the if block:

while condition:
  #This code is repeated as long as "condition" is True

By design, while loops are centred around the idea of operating until a certain goal is met. For example, this could be adding up numbers until a certain value is reached, or a certain number of times if a counter variable is used.

Let’s look at a concrete example:

#A counter variable
counter = 0

#While the counter is lesser than 10, repeat...
while counter < 10:
  #Print the value
  print(counter)
  #Increment the counter
  counter = counter + 1

In this case, we are presented with a simple loop that prints numbers from an initial value of 0 to a maximal value of 9. Note that the condition is formatted the same way as it was in conditional statements: in all cases, those conditions are boolean expressions and are bound by the same rules. This means that you can use any of the operators we discussed to put together while loop conditions that fit your needs.

Also note the last statement of the loop body: counter = counter + 1. Consider what happens if this statement wouldn’t be present:

  1. Set counter to 0
  2. Check if counter is lesser than 10
  3. Print current counter
  4. Increment counter
  5. Go back to 1.

In this scenario, the loop never ends as the condition counter < 10 is never broken! This is an infinite loop and will cause your script to run until manually terminated. Because it’s neither a syntax or language-related error, no formal exception will be raised by the interpreter. In fact, in some cases, this sort of infinite loop behaviour might even be desirable (but we’ll talk about it later)! In general, however, this is to be avoided as most scripts are meant to have a beginning and an end.

2.2 for loops

Much like their while counterpart, for loops will repeat the code that they contain. The major difference between the two is, again, semantic: a for loop will repeat an operation over a collection rather than until a certain condition is met. They will repeat a certain operation “for all items in a given set of items”:

for item in collection:
  #Code that manipulates the item

We will discuss collections in the next lesson, but for now, let’s consider strings, which are essentially collections of characters. If we apply the previous model to a string, we would then get a for loop structure like the following:

for character in "Hello, World!":
  #Do something with each character

As the loop “walks through” the string "Hello, World!", each character is plucked from it and stored temporarily in character. From there, each character can be manipulated individually. We could, for instance, choose to print each character on a line:

for character in "Hello, World!":
  print(character)

Collections can also be a range of numbers generated using the range(min, max, step) function, which accepts three input parameters:

Input Required Effect
min No Sets the range minimum (inclusive)
max Yes Sets the range maximum (exclusive)
step No Sets the jump between each number in the range

Since only the max parameter is required, any single parameter given to range() will be used as a maximum. However, if you choose to give range() multiple parameters, you need to ensure the order in which they are supplied. Enter the following statements in the interactive Python console to see their effect firsthand:

#Produces the range [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]
list(range(5))

#Produces the range [2, 3, 4]
list(range(2,5))

#Produces the range [0, 2, 4]
list(range(0, 5, 2))

Note: we had to wrap our calls to range() in a list() function to convert each range to a list that we can view. If you choose to use a range in a for loop, you do not need to add this extra step.

Since the min parameter has to come first in any multi-parameter usage of range(), to set the step parameter you will also have to explicitly set min, even if it means using the default value (0).

Combining the range() function with our previously defined for loop, we can produce a loop that will process each number individually:

"""
Prints each number in the given range.
Our range parameters are min=0, max=10, step=2
Our range is [0, 2, 4, 6, 8]
"""
for number in range(0,10,2):
  print(number)`

2.3 Converting while to for and back

As we mentioned earlier, the main difference between while and for loops was how the iterative process was phrased. In the former, we repeat an operation as long as a condition is true and in the latter, we repeat an operation over a range of values or items in a set. Since the difference isn’t functional, we can often rewrite a while loop into a for loop and vice-versa.

Let’s take for example our previous loop example, which prints each number in the range [0, 2, 4, 6, 8]:

for number in range(0,10,2):
  print(number)`

To convert this to a while loop, we first need to establish which steps our new structure should go through:

  1. Initially, number = 0;
  2. If number < 10;
    1. Print number;
    2. Increment number by 2 such that we skip the odd values
    3. Back to 2.
  3. Terminate script

We notice that the condition is essentially phrased as have we reached the value max yet?, the min became the initial condition for number and the step has been converted to a statement which increments the value of number by 2.

Using the list of steps above, we can write down the while implementation:

number = 0

while number < 10:
  print(number)
  number = number + 2

Note that while both loops are written differently, they are functionality the same.

This sort of conversion has one major advantage: as you can see from the examples above, in some cases, a while formulation is more concise, whereas in others, for loops will produce shorter scripts. It’s also a matter of preference: if you are struggling to write a while loop for a certain task, a for loop might offer a simpler alternative.

3. Concrete examples

Now that we know about loops and conditions, which essentially allow us to repeat tasks and to selectively execute code, we can implement complex behaviour in our scripts. Let’s look at some examples that could be made more interesting using a combination of iteration and conditional execution.

3.1 Temperature conversion

Earlier, we discussed the idea of using conditionals as validation to ensure that a user cannot proceed with operations before submitting valid input. In this case, this could take the form of a loop that can only be exited if the entered input is a valid number:

#Give an initial value to the variable that will contain our user input
user_in = 0

#Repeat forever
while True:
  #Grab user input
  user_in = input("Enter a temperature in Celsius to convert to Kelvin: ")

  #If the temperature is higher than the absolute minimum for Celsius, exit the loop
  if float(user_in) >= -273.15:
    break
  #Otherwise, print error message
  else:
    print("Invalid value!")

#Once our, convert the temperature, assumed to be valid
kelvin_temp = float(user_in) + 273.15

#Print the results
print(user_in + " degrees Celsius is equivalent to " + str(kelvin_temp) + " degrees Kelvin.")

By using an infinite loop that is manually exited if the entered value is valid, we can force the user to continuously enter values until a satisfactory temperature is given. In this case, the while traps the user until the if condition, which validates the input, is satisfied.

entry.title: Control flow
entry.content:
True/False questions

  1. Any while loop can be rewritten as a for loop.
  2. It is impossible to create infinite loops with for loops.
  3. The range() function can be used without any parameter, in which case the default values are min=0 and max=10.
  4. Loops require the same kind of indentation as other blocks.
  5. Conditional blocks and loops cannot be nested within each other.
  6. Infinite loops are not always undesirable.

Short answer questions

  1. What is one useful case where an infinite loop is a desirable feature?
  2. Describe the different parameters of the range() function and how they affect the function’s output.
  3. How can you convert a while loop to a for loop?
  4. What do you need to be careful about in order to prevent infinite loops?

entry.title: Data structure basics
entry.content:
In this lesson

In this lesson, we learn about how we can organize our data using built-in structures such as tuples, lists and dictionaries.

  1. Data structures
  2. Tuples
    1. Creating tuples
    2. Accessing tuples
    3. The length of collections
  3. Lists
    1. Creating lists
    2. Accessing and editing lists
    3. Growing and shrinking lists
  4. Dictionaries
    1. Creating dictionaries
    2. Accessing and editing dictionaries
    3. Dictionary functions
  5. Collections and loops

1. Data structures

Until now, we have stored single pieces of data in variables. This allowed us to add persistence to our calculations and use the results from previous operations as input for the next. While useful for datum that stands on its own, using variables in the way we have been quickly becomes impractical if we have collections of data that are related in some way.

To illustrate this limit to single-value variables, imagine an experiment where 100 different measurements were collected. Using what we know, storing this data would require the creationg of 100 different variables, producing scripts that quickly become hard to manage, if manageable at all. As we will see later in this lesson, storing these datapoints in separate variables also prevents us from using what we know of loops to iteratively repeat operations on all the data collected.

This is where data structures come in. Python provides us with three primary structures which will allow us to store large amounts of data in an organized fashion that is compatible with loops: tuples, lists and dictionaries. These structures will still be expressed as variables, but will no longer contain single datum. Instead, they will contain a collection of data accessible through indices or keys.

In the discussion that follows, we will call our structures collections, as the next lesson will reveal that we can build our own data structures whose goal isn’t to store large amounts of data at once but to store data in a specific way depending on our needs.

2. Tuples

Tuples are the simplest type of collection available in Python. They represent vectors and are used to create “bundles” of closely-related data that aren’t meant to be edited. For example, we might want to store coordinates, measurement/readings and grouped return values with tuples as none of these are meant to be directly edited; the data they contain is however used in further operations.

2.1 Creating tuples

Creating tuples can be done in a handful of ways:

Using a constructor

Constructors are functions that can generate objects. In the present case, they will generate a default tuple, which is empty. While the read-only nature of tuples makes the constructor useless on its own, its main use will be conversion:

#Creating an empty tuple using the tuple() constructor
my_tuple = tuple()

In the example above, printing the value of my_tuple is (), which represents an empty tuple.

Giving any iterable to our constructor will convert it to a tuple, separating its parts into a list of comma separated elements:

#Splitting a string into a tuple of characters
my_chars = tuple("Hello")

Once converted, my_chars contains ("H", "e", "l", "l", "o"), which is the tuple containing all the iterable elements of the string "Hello".

From this, we can notice a pattern: tuples are comma-separated lists of items surrounded by parentheses.

Using values directly

We can also create tuples by feeding values directly into a variable as a comma-separated list:

numbers = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5
numbers2 = (1, 2, 3, 4, 5)

In the above case, whether you surround your list by parentheses or not, the result will be the same: a tuple containing the values is created and printing either variables will result in (1, 2, 3, 4, 5).

2.2 Accessing tuples

Tuples are classified as ordered collections: elements within tuples have a set position that represents where they are in the structure. We can exploit this property to access single elements.

The position of elements inside of ordered collections like the tuple is represented by the element’s index. Indices are integers ranging from 0 to len(collection) - 1, as such, the first index is 0 and the last is the length of the collection minus 1.

Consider the following tuple, which we created earlier:

numbers = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6

Accessing any of the elements using indices can be done using the model collection[index]. As such, numbers[0] would pull the first element off the numbers tuple, while numbers[5] would pull the last (since the length of our collection is 6, the maximal index is 6 - 1 = 5).

Values pulled from collections can be used just like any other variables would (as long as you do not attempt to edit a value stored in a tuple directly, since tuples are read-only):

#Print the sum of the first two items of the tuple
print(numbers[0]+numbers[1])

#Store a copy of the third value in a variable that you can edit
third = numbers[2]
#Here, you can edit `third` because the variable `third` contains a copy of the read-only value. The copy can be edited.
third = third + 1
print(third)

Be careful

Using indices that are outside of the valid range for a certain collection will cause errors. For instance, in our previous numbers tuple, attempting to access numbers[10] will raise an error and halt the execution of your script because the index you are trying to access is considered unsafe.

2.3 The length of collections

Just like in the case of strings, the length of any collection can be obtained using len(). In this case, calling len(numbers) will return an integer representing the length of the collection numbers.

As such, accessing the last element of a collection, no matter what its length is, can be achieved by using collection[len(collection) - 1] (or access the element of collection that is at index len(collection) - 1).

3. Lists

Lists are another type of ordered collection. Just like tuples, they can contain pieces of data indexed by position. However, contrarily to tuples, lists can be edited – as such, they can grow or shrink depending on your needs.

Because they are not read-only, lists will also possess a certain number of functions that will help you manipulate them.

3.1 Creating lists

Lists can be created using the two standard methods outlined in Creating tuples:

Using a constructor

#Create an empty list that can be expanded later
my_list = list()

#Create a list from another iterable
letters = list("Hello")

Note that we can also convert a tuple to a list to make it editable. We can use the list() constructor to do so by passing a tuple to it as a parameter:

my_tuple = 1, 2, 3
my_list = list(my_tuple)

While my_tuple is read-only, my_list is not and contains the same values as my_tuple. Of course, the opposite can also be achieved: the tuple() constructor can convert a list back into a tuple.

Using values

my_numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

Note that we used the square brackets [] instead of parentheses. This is what differentiates the list from the tuple when declaring using values.

3.2 Accessing and editing lists

Using the same indexing scheme as with the tuples, we can access elements from a list:

my_list = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]

#Prints 1
print(my_list[0])

#Prints 6
print(my_list[len(my_list)-1])

Because our lists are editable, however, we can now use the assignment operator = to replace existing values:

#Replace the first value of the list with 99
my_list[0] = 99

print(my_list)
#[99, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]

This only allows you to edit existing elements of a list, the next section will cover growing or shrinking a list.

3.3 Growing and shrinking lists

The previous usage of indices only covered indices within the bounds [0, len(collection) - 1]. As such, we cannot use it to append new items to a list or otherwise alter the list in a way that would change its length.

This is where the List functions come into play. Just like you might’ve seen with strings, lists have a certain number of functions that can be used to alter their contents.

Function Effects
append(item) Adds item to the end of the list, growing it.
insert(index, item) Inserts item at index index, provided the index exists in the list.
remove(item) Removes the first occurrence of item in the list
pop(index) Removes the item at index index from the list. If no index is given, removes the last item.

Any of the above functions will alter the list in a way that either grows or shrinks it. The usage model is always the same: collection.function():

my_list = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

my_list.append(6) 
#[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]

my_list.insert(1,2)
#[1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]

my_list.remove(4)
#[1, 2, 2, 3, 5, 6]

my_list.pop(2)
#[1, 2, 3, 5, 6]

Notice that any of the above functions will change the length of the list. As such, when using lists, it becomes increasingly important to use len(x) when referring to the collection’s length. This way, you can ensure that no matter what the condition of the list is, the maximal index is known.

4. Dictionaries

The third primary collection that we will discuss is the odd one out. While lists and tuples were ordered collections in which elements were ordered by position/indices, dictionaries are best described as unordered collections: the position of elements within the structure is irrelevant, what counts is the keys they are associated with.

You can visualize dictionaries as “bags” of data in which each datum is attached to a unique label. We will refer to the combination of datum and label as key/value pairs.

4.1 Creating dictionaries

Much like the previous two collections, dictionaries can be created using constructors and values:

Using constructors

Following the same pattern as list() and tuple(), the dict() constructor can be used to create empty dictionaries or convert pre-existing data structures into dictionaries.

#Creates an empty dictionary
my_dict = dict()

Conversion is not as straightforward as with lists and tuples because instead of having an ordered sequence of items, we now have key/value pairs, each of which is represented by two elements of data.

We can use the dict() constructor to build a dictionary from a list of tuples in which tuples represent key/value pairs:

#A list of key/value pairs
key_values = [("first", 1), ("second", 2)]
my_dict = dict(key_values)

Using values

You can also initialize a dictionary by using a sequence of key/value pairs formatted as follows:

my_dict = {"first": 1, "second": 2}

Note the use of {} braces. Much like tuples and parentheses, and lists and square brackets, the braces are associated with dictionaries. Inside those braces is a comma-separated list of pairs of the form key: value.

4.2 Accessing and editing dictionaries

As we mentioned before, dictionaries do not have indices because they are not ordered. However, we can substitute indices for keys and use the same collection[key] format to access and edit entries:

foods = {"Orange": "Fruit", "Tomato": "Who knows.", "Hot dog": "Definitely not a fruit"}

#Prints "Fruit"
print(foods["Orange"])

#Prints "Definitely not a fruit"
print(foods["Hot dog"])

#Changes the value associated with the key "Orange"
foods["Orange"] = "A yummy snack"

Moreover, because we are dealing with keys instead of indices, insertion can be done by specifying a key that isn’t already in the dictionary and assigning a value to it:

foods["Hamburger"] = "Patties on a bun"

In this case, the foods dictionary is grown by one key/value pair.

To achieve the opposite, you can use the del keyword:

del foods["Orange"]

Once the statement above is executed, the key "Orange" no longer is in the dictionary foods. This also removes the value associated with the key.

Be careful

Accessing a dictionary using a key that doesn’t exist but without assigning a new value will cause an error, much like accessing an index that is out of bounds. To avoid this problem, you can use the get(x) function mentioned in the following section.

4.3 Dictionary functions

Much like lists, dictionaries have a handful of functions that you can use on them:

Function Effect
get(x) Returns the value associated with the key x or None is x doesn’t exist.
values() Returns a list of all the values present in the dictionary.
keys() Returns a list of all the keys present in the dictionary.
items() Returns a list of tuples representing all the key/value pairs.
update(x) Merges the current dictionary with the dictionary x

You can use these functions the same way you would use list functions:

foods = {"Orange": "Fruit", "Tomato": "Who knows.", "Hot dog": "Definitely not a fruit"}

drinks = {"Pop": "Fizzy drinks", "Orange juice": "Almost a fruit"}

#Prints a list of values contained in the foods dictionary
print(list(foods.values()))

#Prints a list of all the keys contained in the drinks dictionary
print(list(drinks.keys()))

#Merges the dictionaries, foods now contains all of drinks.
foods.update(drinks)

5. Collections and loops

Here and there, we mentioned the term enumerable when describing collections and strings. The term itself neans that the value on which it is applied can be looped over and processed piece by piece.

In the context of strings, using a loop would allow us to get individual characters, as we have seen earlier:

for character in "Hello, world!":
  print(character)

In the case of ordered collections, the same structure would simply loop over the items in-order:

numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

for num in numbers:
  print(num)

In this case, num will take the value of each item in numbers sequentially.

We can also use our range() function to generate indices. Remember that range() will generate a range of numbers between 0 (unless set to another minimum) and the given maximum. As such, the valid indices in numbers can be described as range(0, len(numbers)) since the maximum is exclusive:

for index in range(0, len(numbers)):
  print(numbers[index])

This last snippet will have the same effect as before: each element of the list will be printed sequentially. The only difference is the approach: in the first, we prioritize the value and discard the index whereas in the second, we prioritize the position and then use each index to get the value.

This model differs sensibly when we deal with dictionaries, as we cannot generate a range of keys. Instead, we will loop through the available keys and use each key to access values:

foods = {"Orange": "Fruit", "Tomato": "Who knows.", "Hot dog": "Definitely not a fruit"}

for food in foods:
  print(food, foods[food])

Here, we go through all the available keys (for food in foods), and at each step, we print both the key (food) and the value (foods[food]).

Be careful

You should always be wary of altering collections while iterating over them. For example, a loop in which you append items to a list might never end if your frame of reference is “until the end of the list”, and one in which you alter the indices might not work very well if you rely on indices to access data.

True/False questions

  1. boolean variables can have three values: True, False and Undefined.
  2. The contains operator checks whether a certain element is inside a collection.
  3. Because they are not primitives, strings cannot be compared using == and !=.
  4. Simple statements can be combined using and and or to build more complex boolean expressions.
  5. A boolean expression always evaluates to a boolean value.
  6. if blocks cannot be used alone; they need an accompanying else block.
  7. elsif blocks allow you to add “alternative conditions” to be evaluated if the ones above are False.
  8. The following block would only print Foo: 
     value = 5

 if value < 10 and value > 2:
   print("Foo")
 if value < 20:
   print("Bar")
 elif value < 30:
   print("Baz")
 else:
   print("Bat")
  9. The function of elif and else blocks can be emulated using if blocks only, but it is much less efficient.
  10. User input using input() is non-blocking: the script will continue running and will not wait for the user’s input unless the value is used in a later statement.
  11. input() can produce integers, floats or strings, depending on the type parameter given to it.

Short answer questions

  1. Explain the role of indentation in blocks such as if/elif/else.
  2. Detail one practical example of how conditional statements can be used in scripts.
  3. What happens if a conversion function such as int() is used on a value that does not contain a number?

Programming questions

  1. Revisit the temperature conversion problem of the last problem set and implement input validation for each of your conversion functions. If the value given to your function is below the minimum acceptable value, you should return the lowest converted value possible, and if the value is above the maximum acceptable value, you should return the highest converted value possible. Think of what the bounds of your input should be.

  2. Using a combination of conditional statements, write a function that converts numerical grades to letter grades. Your overall script should use user input methods to ask the user for a numerical grade to convert and should print out a sentence in which the original entered grade and the converted garde are embedded.

  3. If your solution in 2. used composite expressions as conditions, can you rework if such that only simple expressions are used?

  4. Recursion is the idea that a function can call itself. By modifying the parameters that are provided to the “inside” call, we can modulate how many times a certain function will run.

    For example, we can write the following function:

     def sum_numbers_between(a,b):
   if a == b:
     return a
   else:
     return a + sum_numbers_between(a+1,b)

 my_sum = sum_numbers_between(0, 10)

 print(my_sum)

    Using the same idea as the one exposed in the snippet above, build a function that sums up all the even numbers between two values a and b where a <= b.

entry.title: Control flow
entry.content:
In this lesson

In this lesson, we discuss how boolean values can be used as conditions, and how structures called conditional statements can help you add depth in your scripts’ behaviour by selectively executing statements based on parameters of your choosing.

  1. Boolean expressions
    1. Comparison operators
    2. Composite statements
    3. Variables in boolean expressions
  2. Conditional statements
    1. if blocks
    2. elif blocks
    3. else blocks
    4. A complete model
  3. A concrete example
  4. EXTRA: Basic user input

1. Boolean expressions

In the previous lesson, we mentioned how the boolean datatype was used to represent values that are either true or false. By themselves, these values aren’t very useful: their true purpose is to be the result of boolean expressions that compare values of other types together.

1.1 Comparison operators

The same way that we can use arithmetic operators on numerical values to produce other numerical values (see Mathematical operations), Python includes a number of comparison operators taken from algebraic inequations. The table below is a collection of such operators:

Operator Significance Example
> Greater than 2 > 1
< Lesser than 1 < 2
>= Greater or equal to 5 >= 1
<= Lesser or equal to 1 <= 5
== Equal to 1 == 1
!= Not equal to 1 != 2

As an experiment, you can use the interactive Python console and enter the statements in the Example column of the last table: you should see that all of them evaluate to True. Similarly, you could modify those statements such that they result in False. These are called boolean expressions.

Note that there also exist operators that do not deal with numbers. For example, == can be used between two strings (i.e. "Marc" != "marc") to compare their contents and in can be used to verify if an element is present in a collection (i.e. "a" in "Marc").

Finally, any expression can be negated using not: "d" not in "Marc".

1.2 Composite statements

When we talked about mathematical operations), we mentioned that simple 2-operand mathematical statements can be combined into bigger, richer expressions. We could take 1 + 1 and combine it with 2 * 8 to obtain (1 + 1) + (2 * 8) using parentheses, for example.

This usage of parentheses to combine simple statements into more complex ones also applies to boolean expressions, which can be connected together using and or or.

As their names imply, these operators will allow you to specify whether both or either conditions involved in a combination need to be true for the whole expression to be true. Here are a few examples of and and or in action:

Statement Evaluates to
(1 > 2) or (2 > 0) True
(1 > 2) an (2 > 0) False
((1 > 0) and (2 > 0)) or (1 < 0) True
((1 > 0) and (2 > 0)) and (1 < 0) False

Of course, any of the operators we mentioned before can be used to make up the simple expressions that are combined using or and and.

1.3 Variables in boolean expressions

In the previous slew of examples, we used literal values to make up our expressions. This kind of expression is, evidently, not that interesting since it never changes. When we discussed variables, we mentioned that they were symbolic replacements for data: this means that you can use variables anywhere in boolean expressions - your expressions can now change based on variables that you set.

my_age = input("What is your age")
is_old = int(my_age) > 40

print(is_old)

In the present example, if the variable my_age is a number over 40, we will print the value True, otherwise we will print False. If you are puzzled by input(), take a look at the previous lesson’s quiz, where input(x) was introduced.

2. Conditional statements

Now that we have established that we can use certain operators to obtain boolean values from the data we are manipulating, we can use the outcome of these expressions to guide which statements get executed and which do not. By using boolean expressions as conditions, we can build blocks, called conditional blocks, that will depend on their given condition(s) to be executed.

2.1 if blocks

The simplest conditional blocks are composed of one single unit: the if block. if blocks have a singular mission: to execute the code they contain if and only if the condition that defines them evaluates to True.

Their general form is as follows:

#Any code here is executed before the if block.

if condition:
  #Code that gets executed if 'condition' is True

#Any code here is executed after the if block.

In the event where the condition given to the if block is False, the block is simply skipped. For example, we could selectively print a message based on a number input by the user:

number = int(input("Enter a number: "))

if number > 10:
  print("The number you entered was bigger than 10!")

In the previous snippet, the print() call is only executed if the number number satisfies the if block’s condition, which is number > 10. Any number that doesn’t meet this criterion will cause the condition to be False and the if block to be skipped entirely.

2.2 elif blocks

Sometimes, the if block alone isn’t enough to describe the behaviour that we want to implement. Since if is skipped if its condition is False, multiple if blocks could be used in chain to implement the behaviour “if not the first, check another condition”:

if condition1:
  #Code that is executed if condition1 == True
if not condition1 and condition2:
  #Code that is executed if the first "if" failed but condition2 is True

This form however gets cumbersome very quickly if you have a series of other conditions to check because you always need to ensure that all the previous conditions are False; since the if blocks are independent from each other, a faulty set of conditions could potentially allow them both to be executed one after the other.

To solve this issue and to simplify the implementation of that sort of behaviour, we introduce the elif statement. elif is functionally the same as if, but stands for “else if”. In combination with an if, an elif will only be executed if the if it’s attached to is skipped. We could rewrite the previous block of code as:

if condition1:
  #Code that is executed if condition1 == True
elif condition2:
  #"elif" implies that condition1  was False and checks condition2

This syntax really shines when you consider cases where you have multiple elif blocks:

if condition1:
  #Code that is executed if condition1 == True
elif condition2:
  #"elif" implies that condition1  was False and checks condition2
elif condition3:
  #"elif" implies that condition1 and condition2 were False and checks condition3
elif condition4:
  #"elif" implies that condition1, condition2 and condition3  was False and checks condition4

If we opted to use a contraption of if blocks alone, we would have to ensure that previous conditions did indeed fail before checking if the new condition is True.

2.3 else blocks

THe else blocks complements the if and elif blocks by providing a “catch-all” scenario. Whenever an else is present following a combination of if and elif blocks, it is executed if and only if all the previous conditional blocks fail. This means that all the blocks that have conditions will be skipped and that the else block will be executed before the script can move on.

The else requires no condition by definition: its condition could be expressed as “none of the previous conditions were true”.

if condition1:
  #Code executed if condition1 is true
elif condition2:
  #Code executed if condition2 is true but condition1 is false
else:
  #If all else fails and both conditions are false, this is executed

2.4 A complete model

Combining all three conditional blocks, we can produce a general model for conditional elements. Any valid conditional structure should…

  • …be opened by an if block; Note: Semantically, it wouldn’t make sense to open with an elif or an else since these both depend on a previous element being false.
  • …feature zero or more elif block, as needed;
  • …feature zero or one else block, as needed.

The combination of blocks that will make up your conditional statements will depend on the behaviour you are trying to implement. As such, not all blocks are relevant to all conditional statements: sometimes, a simple if is enough, but in other cases, several elif blocks are needed to get it right.

if condition1:
  """
  Mandatory block for any conditional statement.
  """
elif condition2:
  """
  Optional block, can be present in multiples, as needed.
  """
else:
  """
  Optional block, can only be present once in a statement.
  """

3. A concrete example

In the previous lesson’s problem set, we introduced a temperature conversion problem. If you experimented with different input values for your conversion process, you probably noticed that not all values are valid.

For example, the absolute zero for Celsius degrees is -273.15C, which means that any value below that shouldn’t be converted and should be flagged as invalid. With conditional statements, input given to the conversion function (or collected from the user via input()) can be validated such that only values within a valid range are considered.

We could then add a conditional statement such as this one to ensure the validity of conversion results:

if temperature < -273.15:
  #Return the minimal Fahrenheit value, or an error code.
else:
  #Compute the conversion as usual

4. EXTRA: Basic user input

The topic of user input was briefly discussed in the last problem set and left to experimentation. In Python, user input can be gathered using the input(x) function, which takes in a parameter, x, that is printed as a prompt before the user gets to type in something and returns the user’s input.

This kind of user input is called blocking because the script will stop and wait after printing the prompt (x), only to resume when the user presses the return key.

Because it is hard to predict exactly what he user will enter, user input is always considered to be a string, this means that depending on what you are capturing, you might have to use the conversion functions we have discussed earlier to adjust the datatype of the user’s input to your needs.

user_input = input("Enter a number: ")

"""
Here, we convert our string to an integer to be able to 
compare it to other numbers.
"""

user_input_num = int(user_input)

if user_input_num < 0:
  print("The number you entered was negative!")
elif user_input_num > 0:
  print("The number was positive!")
else:
  print("You entered 0.")

Later, we will cover the scenario where we expect the user to enter a number and a non-numerical value is entered. This will be covered by exception-handling. For now, we can simply assume that the user always answers our queries with the appropriate data.

entry.title: Web scraping
entry.content:
In this lesson

In this lesson, we will look at the interactive Python console. We will explore the notion of variables and methods, and review definitions that will follow us for the rest of our adventure.

  1. Using the interactive console
  2. Variables
    1. Primitives and Objects
    2. Creating and modifying variables

1. Using the interactive console

For the first part of this lesson, you can use the interactive console through a Command Prompt/Terminal (by opening a Command Prompt/Terminal and typing python) or through IDLE. Since IDLE’s interactive console is just a graphical interface wrapped around the regular Python console, you shouldn’t see any difference in function.

Before we get started, consider a few things about the interactive console:

  1. It has memory. Any variable or method defined in the console will exist and be accessible until the console is terminated. This allows us to type long scripts one statement at a time and keep the results of each statement at hand for the next;
  2. It can be terminated at any time by using the exit statement exit();
  3. If the console is busy with a task, you can force termination using the Control/Command key and C, this is called a keyboard interrupt;
  4. Any statement that produces output will print out its output on the line following a statement;
  5. You can view the contents of a variable at any time by using its name as a statement.

1.1 Mathematical operations

The most basic thing the interactive console can do it basic arithmetic. If you use any mathematical operation as a statement, you should see the results printed below. All the basic operators taught in algebra are valid. As such, we can experiment and produce the following:

Various arithmetic operations in the console

Note that just like in classical algebra, you can use parentheses to group operations together, and chained operations such as (1 + 1) * (12 * 50) can be composed from simpler ones.

2. Variables

What differentiates the interactive console from a simple pocket calculator is its ability to store and manipulate different kinds of data. To achieve this, we will use variables. Variables in Python are no different from their algebraic counterparts: they act as a symbolic replacement for data. This means that once defined, a variable can be inserted in other operations and behave as if you had inserted the data is contains.

Before we create our own, however, we should define a few basic data types available in Python: these data types will determine what kind of data is stored in a variable and what sort of operations we can apply on said variable.

2.1 Primitives and Objects

Python data types can be separated into two classes: primitives and objects. The separating criterion is fairly simple: primitives can be represented by a single numerical value while objects require a bigger structure stored in memory, to which the variable points. Below are the three main primitive types we will be using most of the time:

Data type Definition Example values
int Integer values 1, -1, 2000000
float Floating-point values 1.1, -1.5
boolean True or false binary values True, False

In addition to these types, we need to define at least one object type: the string. Strings are collections of characters and can contain single characters, words, sentences and even entire books.

Data type Definition Example values
str Strings, any set of character surrounded by single or double quotation marks "Hello, world!", "A"

2.2 Operations on primitives

All of the arithmetic operations we have experimented with in the [first section] of this lesson are applicable to any primitive. In the case of True and False (boolean values), those will be interpreted as 1 and 0 respectively. As such, the following is possible:

Arithmetic using boolean values

This outlines what we said earlier: any primitive value can be represented as a number.

2.3 Operations on objects

Operations on objects are a bit trickier. Because objects are complex structures, no two object types have the same operations! Because object operations are defined on a case by case basis, we’ll look at the one object we considered so far: the string.

While strings cannot be divided or subtracted from one another, two operations exist:

Operation Definition
+ Concatenation, or the union of two or more strings
* Multiplication, or the act of repeating strings

The first operation, concatenation, allows you to make longer strings out of shorter ones. This means that given three strings, we can use the + operator to form a new longer one that represents the sum of the three:

Concatenating strings

The same way, using the * operator will duplicate and concatenate strings. For example, typing "hello" * 2 would result in the string "hellohello"; the initial string would be repeated twice, and the repetitions concatenated.

2.4 Operations and data types

The operations defined earlier only apply between items of the same type (either primitive or object). As such, while you can add a float to an int, you cannot concatenate a string to a number directly as either element has a different definition of what the operation + should do. To solve this issue, you can convert one data type to the other, when possible. To do so, we will introduce three functions (also called methods):

Method Definition
str(x) If possible, converts the value x to a string. This would, for example, convert the integer 1 to the string "1".
int(x) If possible, converts the value x to an integer.
float(x) If possible, convers the value x to a float.

These conversions are limited: only strings representing numbers can be converted to proper numbers using float(x) and int(x), but any float, integer or boolean can be converted to a string using str(x).

We can use these functions to combine data of different types. Using this, we could write the following statement:

"Hello! I am " + str(27) + " and I like Python."

Without the type conversion, an error would occur:

TypeError during concatenation

2.2 Creating and modifying variables

As we’ve seen in the previous sections, we can easily manipulate raw data in the interactive console. However, one large issue that stops us from going forward is data persistence. While we can apply operations on numbers and strings, we have yet to save anything to memory! This is where variables come in. As we said earlier, variables are symbolic replacements for data. Once defined, a variable and the data is contains can be substituted in any other statement.

Python being a soft-typed language, we do not need to handle which data type each variable stores; the interpreter will handle that seamlessly as we use our variables. This results in a very simple model for the definition of variables:

my_variable = some_value

Using this model, you can create variables of any of the types we’ve manipulated before:

age = 27
height = 180.1
name = "Marc

Since variables are symbolic replacements, we can then use those variables by inserting their names, age, height and name where appropriate. We could make use of concatenation with all three to produce a sentence with embedded data:

sentence = "Hello! My name is " + name + " and I am " + str(age) + " years old. I am " + str(height) + " centimetres high."

As we’ve seen before, the calls to str(x) will convert age and height from their respective primitive types to strings, then the + will concatenate all those strings together into Hello! My name is Marc and I am 27 years old. I am 180.1 centimetres high.

  4. Any statement that produces output will print out its output on the line following a statement;
  5. You can view the contents of a variable at any time by using its name as a statement.

1.1 Mathematical operations

The most basic thing the interactive console can do it basic arithmetic. If you use any mathematical operation as a statement, you should see the results printed below. All the basic operators taught in algebra are valid. As such, we can experiment and produce the following:

Various arithmetic operations in the console

Note that just like in classical algebra, you can use parentheses to group operations together, and chained operations such as (1 + 1) * (12 * 50) can be composed from simpler ones.

2. Variables

What differentiates the interactive console from a simple pocket calculator is its ability to store and manipulate different kinds of data. To achieve this, we will use variables. Variables in Python are no different from their algebraic counterparts: they act as a symbolic replacement for data. This means that once defined, a variable can be inserted in other operations and behave as if you had inserted the data is contains.

Before we create our own, however, we should define a few basic data types available in Python: these data types will determine what kind of data is stored in a variable and what sort of operations we can apply on said variable.

2.1 Primitives and Objects

Python data types can be separated into two classes: primitives and objects. The separating criterion is fairly simple: primitives can be represented by a single numerical value while objects require a bigger structure stored in memory, to which the variable points. Below are the three main primitive types we will be using most of the time:

Data type Definition Example values
int Integer values 1, -1, 2000000
float Floating-point values 1.1, -1.5
boolean True or false binary values True, False

In addition to these types, we need to define at least one object type: the string. Strings are collections of characters and can contain single characters, words, sentences and even entire books.

Data type Definition Example values
str Strings, any set of character surrounded by single or double quotation marks "Hello, world!", "A"

2.2 Operations on primitives

All of the arithmetic operations we have experimented with in the first section of this lesson are applicable to any primitive. In the case of True and False (boolean values), those will be interpreted as 1 and 0 respectively. As such, the following is possible:

Arithmetic using boolean values

This outlines what we said earlier: any primitive value can be represented as a number.

2.3 Operations on objects

Operations on objects are a bit trickier. Because objects are complex structures, no two object types have the same operations! Because object operations are defined on a case by case basis, we’ll look at the one object we considered so far: the string.

While strings cannot be divided or subtracted from one another, two operations exist:

Operation Definition
+ Concatenation, or the union of two or more strings
* Multiplication, or the act of repeating strings

The first operation, concatenation, allows you to make longer strings out of shorter ones. This means that given three strings, we can use the + operator to form a new longer one that represents the sum of the three:

Concatenating strings

The same way, using the * operator will duplicate and concatenate strings. For example, typing "hello" * 2 would result in the string "hellohello"; the initial string would be repeated twice, and the repetitions concatenated.

2.4 Operations and data types

The operations defined earlier only apply between items of the same type (either primitive or object). As such, while you can add a float to an int, you cannot concatenate a string to a number directly as either element has a different definition of what the operation + should do. To solve this issue, you can convert one data type to the other, when possible. To do so, we will introduce three functions (also called functions):

Function Definition
str(x) If possible, converts the value x to a string. This would, for example, convert the integer 1 to the string "1".
int(x) If possible, converts the value x to an integer.
float(x) If possible, convers the value x to a float.

These conversions are limited: only strings representing numbers can be converted to proper numbers using float(x) and int(x), but any float, integer or boolean can be converted to a string using str(x).

We can use these functions to combine data of different types. Using this, we could write the following statement:

"Hello! I am " + str(27) + " and I like Python."

Without the type conversion, an error would occur:

TypeError during concatenation

2.5 Creating and modifying variables

As we’ve seen in the previous sections, we can easily manipulate raw data in the interactive console. However, one large issue that stops us from going forward is data persistence. While we can apply operations on numbers and strings, we have yet to save anything to memory! This is where variables come in. As we said earlier, variables are symbolic replacements for data. Once defined, a variable and the data is contains can be substituted in any other statement.

Python being a soft-typed language, we do not need to handle which data type each variable stores; the interpreter will handle that seamlessly as we use our variables. This results in a very simple model for the definition of variables:

my_variable = some_value

Using this model, you can create variables of any of the types we’ve manipulated before:

age = 27
height = 180.1
name = "Marc"

Since variables are symbolic replacements, we can then use those variables by inserting their names, age, height and name where appropriate. We could make use of concatenation with all three to produce a sentence with embedded data:

sentence = "Hello! My name is " + name + " and I am " + str(age) + " years old. I am " + str(height) + " centimetres high."

As we’ve seen before, the calls to str(x) will convert age and height from their respective primitive types to strings, then the + will concatenate all those strings together into Hello! My name is Marc and I am 27 years old. I am 180.1 centimetres high.

3. Writing scripts

To progress further and to start building any sort of project, we will need to be able to execute a multitude of statements at once. To accomplish this, we will write scripts, or sequences of statements that will be executed all at once instead of one-by-one as we did so far in the interactive console.

To write a script, simply save a sequence of statements, one per line, in a file bearing the extension .py. This will be called a Python script file. To execute it all at once, we will not use the interactive console, as it is meant for line-by-line execution. We will turn out attention to IDLE.

Using IDLE, you can create a new script file through the File menu. This opens up a new window in which you can type your script. Just like any other text file, you can save and open scripts using IDLE; this way, you can revisit them later as needed. Once your script file contains statements and is saved, the Run menu will allow you to execute your script file (Run module).

For example, consider the follow sample script: it contains our last experiment with concatenation:

age = 27
height = 180.1
name = "Marc"

sentence = "Hello! My name is " + name + " and I am " + str(age) + " years old. I am " + str(height) + " centimetres high."

print(sentence)

When executing your script, the interpreter will work its way from the top to the bottom and execute your statements one at a time. Since the interpreter is never aware of the whole file, it will only raise an error if it tries to execute a faulty statement.

Notice the use of print(x). Since we are no longer in the interactive console, output is not longer automatically printed to the screen. The print function print(x) will solve that issue by printing the string or variable given to it as parameter.

4. Functions

Functions are meant to be blocks of code you can reuse. Just like functions in mathematics, they can accept input and produce output. Python has dozens of built-in functions, a few of which we’ve seen previously:

Function Definition
str(x) If possible, converts the value x to a string. This would, for example, convert the integer 1 to the string "1".
int(x) If possible, converts the value x to an integer.
float(x) If possible, convers the value x to a float.
print(x) Prints the value of x to the screen.

As we go forward, we will add more functions to this list, but the most important part about Python functions isn’t that the language offers a lot of them out-of-the-box but rather than you can make your own.

The basic model to define a function introduces the def keyword:

def my_function(input):
  #Code that is executed when the function is called.

  return output

A few things to consider:

  1. The def keyword indicates that a function is being defined;
  2. my_function is the given name of our function, we will use it to call our function later (i.e. my_function());
  3. input is a comma-separated list of items that will act as variables within the function;
  4. The return keyword “hands back” the output of the function to whoever called the function. An example of this is str(x), which returns a string made from the value of x.

Reusing our previous example in which we build a string that introduced us, we could write a function that returns our concatenated string and takes the three elements as input:

def introduce_myself(name, age, height):
  output = "Hello! My name is " + name + " and I am " + str(age) +  " years old. I am " + height + " centimetres high."

  return output

Once defined, we can use introduce_myself() anywhere in our script and as long as we give it the right parameters (a string, an integer and a float, in that order), it will produce the right output.

For example, we can use introduce_myself("Marc", 27, 180.1) and get the same output string as before.

4.1 Indentation

You might have noticed that not all lines are on the same level in the previous example. This is not for looks: it’s by design. Blocks of code such as functions use indentation as delimiters in Python, each level being the equivalent of “brackets” that contain the block’s body.

Every time we will declare a block (such as the def statement in the previous example), we will give any following statement that is part of the block one extra level of indentation. As such, we will obtain a layout such as the following:

def my_function1():
  #Code that is in the function "my_function1"

def my_function2():
  #Code that is in the function "my_function2"

#Code that is not in any of the function but that is in the file.
#Any code at this level is executed if you run your script.

Note that any code that is at the “base” level of your script is executed when your script is run.

5. Comments

You might have noticed sentences embedded in code blocks on lines that start with #. These are called comments. Comments are notes left by the programmer to contextualize code, explain the logic of a certain block or provide guidance on things left to do or fix.

You can add comments to your code two ways:


# You can write single-line comments using the hashbang sign before the comment text.

"""
You can also use three consecutive quotation marks to open a block comment
that can span over multiple lines. Another set of three quotation marks will
close the block comment.
"""

Comments are ignored by the interpreter and do not alter the behaviour of your script. You are strongly encouraged to comment your code, as logic that is self-evident today might not remain so through time, and code that you would share might raise questions from other programmers.
